fields.description:
We have multiple agile teams using Jira agile and we've been using it for a little over 2 years now. The view has greatly improved since GreenHopper days, but we have some a few significant issues that cause our team to have to work around Jira that I wanted to raise to you:

1. Accounting for both hours and story points is challenging: Our team estimates our sprint and measures our sprint success by velocity and story points, but we use hours as a gut check during our planning to understand capacity this is a challenge for many reasons:
- If we have hours enabled our burndown chart only burns down by hours we aren't tracking, not story points which we want. We need to have hours enabled in order to do detailed level tasking. This makes our burndown chart useless for us
- On the plan view, when we select an individual on the team to see how their hours line up we can only see the tickets where they are assigned to the parent level ticket. This doesn't work for us as we have multiple team members assigned to subtasks on each ticket it, so we have to keep track on each person's hours on a separate spreadsheet during planning.

Summary of team info on the "Work" view
- Some of our teams are moving back to physical scrum boards during their standups because the "work" view is too busy as it's impossible to see what's in a sprint without scrolling down and we want to see if all on one screen.
- There really isn't a good way to view stories & subtasks. We use the swimlane option of having parent stories across the view with the subtasks showing, the parent tickets always seem to get lost in that view. The ability to customize the work view more would be appreciated. We want to be able to easily toggle between sprint summary view and a detailed level view

Accounting for Story Point Changes & Velocity Calculations
- If you add / change story points to a story after a sprint has started or add a story with points to a sprint after it's started than the numbers aren't on the sprint report. This is really annoying as I have to click on each ticket that doesn't have a story point listed and do my own manual calculations.
- Also, I have a whole separate spreadsheet for each sprint team that breaks down the the team's historical performance. This is how we determine the "average velocity per person on the team per day" and we used this to estimate the velocity during planning based on the team's availability. Having that as part of reporting would be awesome!
fields.summary: Jira Agile Board View Summary / Role up view

fields.description:
As a agile team member I want to have the status of an issue regarding (for instance) INVEST criteria visualized on the scrum board's planning page in order to quickly see which issues are ready for being included into the next sprint.

In detail:
Our company has chosen to visualize the result of checking an issue for INVEST criteria by using the *traffic light plugin* ("de.polscheit.jira.plugins.traffic-light_status"). After a team member has checked all criteria and found them acceptable, the traffic light is switched to green, signalling the issue is ready for sprint. This works well in the normal issue detail view but
- neither can the traffic light be visualized directly in the list of issues to be ranked and placed into the spring in sprint planning mode
- nor can the traffic light field be added to the issue detail view shown right of this list if an issue is clicked. It is simply not in the list of available fields, even if I configure it as "global" (all projects, all issue types).

I am aware that we could, in principle use a plain text field or yet another issue status to hold the same information, but a traffic light visualizes the "sprint readiness" much better imho.
fields.summary: Allow custom rendered fields to be displayed on sprint planning board

fields.description:
I regularly use the classic agile gadget on dashboards to evaluate the overall progress of large projects.  We typically avoid story points and instead look at solely at remaining hours (hours tab).  So we're looking at the classic agile gadget for a 12-18 month period.  When I look at the red line, it's automatically set to start with the amount of work remaining in hours on the start date set in the gadget's configuration and then is rendered in a straight line where 0 is at the end date as set in the configuration.  

This is nice for uses where the number of hours on the start date is equivalent to the capacity of your team given some velocity (I run a model for long projects that assumes N developers at M%utilization thereby giving me a capacity in terms of how much available scope measured in time that the team can handle at any date in the project); however, in reality our backlogs are never quite built so perfectly, so what I'd like to do is have the ability to add another line to the burndown gadget that represents the capacity of the team.  This would be in addition to the current red line.

I would want to specify the following information:

1. Start date
2. Capacity on start date measured in hours
3. End date
4. Remaining amount of work left on end date.  It would probably be ok to set this to 0 and I could probably make do with not being able to configure this value.

Then the software would render a line based on that information.  This would allow me to see how I've modeled effort and then as I'm monitoring the team's progress, the goal would be to make sure my green line stays near this model line.  It would also make it very clear if I had room in my model to add scope or if I had to start thinking about cutting scope.

Additionally it'd be nice to allow hiding of the currently implemented red line.

One additional problem that the current implementation of the red line in the gadget imposes is that you search for a date in time where the amount of work in the backlog approximates the team's capacity that you are trying to model and you are then not able to see anything prior to this.

I know this may not be how folks intended the tool to be used in terms of long projects with burndown charts spanning many months, but the tool does a great job for this type of project except for the issue mentioned here.

I'm running jira 6.0.8 and have been unable to find anything in the docs for future versions that suggest this is possible.
fields.summary: Create a custom line with a user-specified particular slope to reflect a custom user-defined capacity model (custom version of the red line)

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Software Server*. Using *JIRA Software Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSWCLOUD-10652].
  {panel}

h3. Summary

Attempting to edit an issue presents with the error "Issue has multiple acive or future sprints" [sic]. This prevents saving the changes to the issue.

The following may appear in the _atlassian-greenhopper.log_:
{code:borderStyle=solid}
2015-12-03 11:08:20,373 http-bio-8080-exec-1099 ERROR lgodbole 668x100203x7 1ou4znq 10.0.0.3,127.0.0.1 /rest/greenhopper/1.0/xboard/issue/details.json [web.rapid.issue.IssueResource] Unable to complete GreenHopper REST method 
java.lang.IllegalStateException: Issue ABC-123 has multiple active or future sprints
	at com.atlassian.greenhopper.service.sprint.SprintIssueServiceImpl$SprintFilterFunction.apply(SprintIssueServiceImpl.java:381)
	at com.atlassian.greenhopper.service.sprint.SprintIssueServiceImpl$SprintFilterFunction.apply(SprintIssueServiceImpl.java:364)
	at com.atlassian.greenhopper.service.ServiceOutcomes.map(ServiceOutcomes.java:38)
	at com.atlassian.greenhopper.service.sprint.SprintIssueServiceImpl.getActiveOrFutureSprintForIssue(SprintIssueServiceImpl.java:235)
	at com.atlassian.greenhopper.web.rapid.issue.IssueResource$1.call(IssueResource.java:127)
	at com.atlassian.greenhopper.web.rapid.issue.IssueResource$1.call(IssueResource.java:106)
	at com.atlassian.greenhopper.web.util.RestCall.response(RestCall.java:42)
	at com.atlassian.greenhopper.web.AbstractResource.createResponse(AbstractResource.java:115)
	at com.atlassian.greenhopper.web.AbstractResource.response(AbstractResource.java:96)
	at com.atlassian.greenhopper.web.rapid.issue.IssueResource.getPageData(IssueResource.java:105)
	at sun.reflect.GeneratedMethodAccessor2080.invoke(Unknown Source)
	at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43)
	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:497)
	at com.atlassian.plugins.rest.common.interceptor.impl.DispatchProviderHelper$ResponseOutInvoker$1.invoke(DispatchProviderHelper.java:234)
{code}

h3. Steps to Reproduce

# Restore an instance with a problematic data set (one that has managed to get multiple Sprint fields onto one edit screen in different tabs).
# Edit the issue and change the sprint field.
# Attempt to save the changes.

h3. Expected Results

The changes are successfully sent.

h3. Actual Results

The changes fail to save and the attached error is presented to the user.

h3. Notes

This is caused by multiple Sprint fields appearing on the edit screen in different tabs. This appears to be caused by an upgrade task. Additionally in earlier versions the spelling of "acive" was incorrect, and has since been updated to "active".

h3. Workaround

Edit the screen for that project and remove the Sprint field from one of the tabs as per [Defining a Screen|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Defining+a+Screen#DefiningaScreen-Editingascreen'sdetails]. This will prevent JIRA Agile from displaying this error.
fields.summary: Cannot edit Sprint field due to Issue having multiple active or future sprints

	at org.apache.coyote.AbstractProtocol$AbstractConnectionHandler.process(AbstractProtocol.java:603)
	at org.apache.tomcat.util.net.JIoEndpoint$SocketProcessor.run(JIoEndpoint.java:312)
	at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(Unknown Source)
	at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(Unknown Source)
	at java.lang.Thread.run(Unknown Source)

{noformat}

h3. Workaround

This appears to fail due to orphaned custom field values that point to an issue that no longer exists. This can be identified with the below SQL:

{code:SQL}
SELECT * 
FROM   customfieldvalue 
WHERE  issue NOT IN (SELECT id 
                     FROM   jiraissue); 
{code}

And fixed with the following:

# Disable JIRA Agile.
# Stop JIRA.
# Backup the database.
# Execute the following:
{code:SQL}
DELETE FROM customfieldvalue 
WHERE  issue NOT IN (SELECT id 
                     FROM   jiraissue);
{code}
# Start JIRA, reindex and re-enable JIRA Agile.
fields.summary: Attempting to upgrade JIRA Agile fails with The replicated index may or may not be correct

fields.description:
When configuring JQL based swimlanes for a rapid board it would be useful to be able to specify JQL execution in a different order than swimlane order.

For example ({color:blue}not real, contrived to illustrate{color}):

{panel:title= Currently must do}

||Name||JQL||
|Critical|priority in (Critical, Blocker) and status != 'Waiting'|
|Queue|status != 'Waiting'|
|Waiting| |

To get issues to fall through to the Waiting swimlane additional criteria needs to be added to JQL for all higher swimlanes.
{panel}

{panel:title=Would like to do something like}

||Display Order||Name||JQL||
|3|Waiting|status = 'Waiting'|
|1|Critical|priority in (Critical, Blocker)|
|2|Queue| |

So the JQL for Waiting is executed first but displayed as the third swimlane down and the 'and status != 'Waiting'' stuff doesn't need to be duplicated on the other swimlanes.
{panel}

*Again, the example is contrived to illustrate.  I am aware that Waiting could be configured as a column.  I don't want to get into a discussion regarding proper use of columns vs swimlanes.*
fields.summary: Decouple JQL execution order from swimlane order

fields.description:
To rank issues in Scrum Board's *Plan Mode*, you need the *Edit Issues* and *Schedule Issues* permission. 
To rank issues in Scrum Board's and Kanban Board's *Work Mode*, you only need the *Schedule Issues* permission. 

Changing the ranks in the Work Mode without the Edit Issues permission will still affect the rank values in the issue's rank field.

This seems inconsistent as they all use the Rank field. Also, the [documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/AGILE/Ranking+an+Issue] says you need only the Schedule Issues permission.
fields.summary: Inconsistent Ranking permissions for Plan and Work Modes in Scrum and Kanban boards

fields.description:
According to the documentation on [Configuring Columns - Setting Column Constraints|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/AGILE/Configuring+Columns#ConfiguringColumns-Enablecolumncontraints]:

{quote}
Constraints specify how many issues a column can contain. You can specify constraints for all columns, or just some of them.

You can choose to exclude sub-tasks from the count. This is useful if you want to constrain the number of major tasks (stories) your team is working on, rather than the total number of individual tasks. This is likely to be more relevant to Scrum teams than to Kanban teams.
{quote}

Reading the docs, I believe the column *should* display only the maximum number set in the column constraint, but it doesn't (tested for both Scrum and Kanban). The only difference will be that column header now had a red line added:

!kanban.png!

!scrum.png!
fields.summary: Improve documentation for column constraints in JIRA Software (and JIRA Agile)

fields.description:
We use the Scheduling permission to control ranking in Agile. We have external customer users that we want to be allowed to rank issues but not edit them, so they have the 'Scheduling Issues' permission but not the 'Edit Issues' permission.

These customer users can drag and drop to rank issues on a Kanban board, so that's fine, but if I create a Scrum board when they try to rank on the Plan view they get the following error:

{quote}
Error

You do not have permission to edit this issue.
{quote}

Why would there be a difference?? The documentaion suggests you just need the Schedule permission, not Edit. This is blocking us from using the boards with customers....

We've tried with J6 (we're running J5) and get the same problem.

Asked this here https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/276970/can-rank-on-kanban-but-not-on-scrum but didn't get an answer.
fields.summary: Can rank on Kanban but not on Scrum

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
We have multiple boards with overlapping project filters; and sometimes it happens that an epic shows up on more than just one of the boards. Some epics contain issues of more than one of the projects (ex. a new feature in an integrated product requires a slight update in the backend, which also needs an update of the UI to allow it to be used).
Depending on whether the board shows all of the epics issues or not, the status indication (both the summary of Total/Completed issues and the small progress bar next to/below the epic name) shows the wrong result.
This caused us to close an epic that wasn't really done, which is not really helping in the longer term...

To reproduce, create two boards referencing two projects, with an epic referencing issues of both projects.
Board A references Project 1 and Project 2, with an Epic belonging to Project 1, having two issues belonging to Project 1 and Project 2 respectively.
Board B references only Project 1, and it shows the Epic.
When looking at Board A, the Epic has a Total Issue count of 2, with a status reflecting the actual issue state.
When looking at Board B, the Epic has a Total Issue count of 1.
If the issue from Project 1 was closed, Board B would show 100% completion on the epic; while Board A shows 50% completion.

We try to mark epics as complete as soon as they reach 100% in order to reduce their numbers; users/POs of Board B would close them early in cases where other projects are involved that arent shown on the Board.
fields.summary: Epic Progress does not include all issues; but only issues visible on the board

fields.description:
The following error is displayed when accessing the Plan mode of a recently imported Jira on OnDemand from a local server.
!board-migration-error.jpeg!
( Error java.lang.NoSuchMethodError: com.atlassian.jira.task.TaskDescriptor.getResult()Ljava/lang/Object; )

*Cause:*
There is an incompatibility with the Jira Agile imported on OnDemand and the current running version on OnDemand 6.3.11.0
(Observer when importing Jira Agile v6.1.6)

*Solution:*
The Jira Agile team informed that this fix has already been worked on and will be available on OnDemand in the next version release: v6.3.12

*Temporal Workaround:*
Upgrade Jira Agile on the local Jira before exporting to OnDemand
fields.summary: NoSuchMethodError in the Plan mode when migrating board

fields.description:
From the 6.3.9 release notes:
{code}When editing the field, you can also search for a sprint by name and JIRA Agile will suggest matching sprints (with sprints from boards /issues that you've recently viewed shown first).{code}

The suggestions provided by the sprint field will also include sprints which are not relevant to the project the current issue belongs to, yet it does allow the issue to be added to it.

Example:
# Create 2 projects, Project A and Project B
# Create 2 boards on existing projects, Board A and Board B corresponding to the previously created projects.
# Create a sprint on each board, Sprint A and Sprint B
# Edit an issue from Project A, from the suggestions list pick Sprint B and update the issue

The filter queries in both boards are set to only display issues from that particular project. (ie project = "Project A" or project = "Project B")

The Plan Board A will now display Sprint B with the issue from Project A assigned to it.
The Work Board A will display both Sprint A and Sprint B

The issue from Project A will not appear on plan and work boards B, Board B will only display Sprint B and issues from Project B

A small note is displayed when adding an issue to a sprint which belongs to a board where the issue is not a results of its search filter, that adding this sprint will change the scope of the sprint. After that, tracking the issue on the boards becomes very unclear, and is not in line with the boards filter query.

The suggested sprints should take the search queries of the boards into account.
fields.summary: Sprint suggestions do not follow board search filters

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Creating a new Rapid Board appears to fail with the error message "The requested board cannot be viewed because it either does not exist or you do not have permission to view it.".

This is displayed in the attached screenshot.

h3. Steps to Reproduce

# Restore an instance with problematic data.
# Create a new board.

h3. Expected Results

The board is created without error.

h3. Actual Results

The board does not appear to be created and the red message is shown.

h3. Notes

This is caused by invalid entries in the user history - specifically references to non existing boards. This can be verified with the following SQL:

{code:SQL}
SELECT *
FROM   userhistoryitem
WHERE  username = 'admin'
       AND entitytype = 'RapidView'
       AND entityid::integer NOT IN (SELECT "ID"
                                     FROM   "AO_60DB71_RAPIDVIEW");
{code}
(i) This is PostgreSQL-specific and may require changing for a different DBMS. Please consult with your DBA.

If this contains references to IDs that do not exist in the below output it is likely the problem described here is occurring:

h3. Workaround

This can be fixed by removing those entries:

# Stop JIRA.
# Backup the database using the native DB tools.
# Execute the following:
{code:SQL}
DELETE
FROM   userhistoryitem 
WHERE  username = 'admin' 
       AND entitytype = 'RapidView' 
       AND entityid::integer NOT IN (SELECT "ID"
                                     FROM   "AO_60DB71_RAPIDVIEW");
{code}
(i) This is PostgreSQL-specific and may require changing for a different DBMS. Please consult with your DBA.
# Start JIRA and test the board creation.
fields.summary: Creating a new Board appears to fail with a message about it not existing or no permissions to view it
